cards.card_body: The **Node REPL** is a way to run JS one line at a time. **REPL** stands for ***Read Evaluate Print Loops***.

###What is Node.js?
**Node.js** is a way to liberate JavaScript from the browser. That way you can build in more robust functionality, like handling direct requests to the computer and dealing with filesystems.
**NPM** is a *package manager*, kinda like PyPi for Python. You can find it [here](https://www.npmjs.com/)

card_children.subcard_body: The Udemy lecture about using and installing NPM is [here](https://www.udemy.com/course/the-complete-web-development-bootcamp/learn/lecture/12384340#overview)

cards.card_body:
### Using external packages in Node
In order to use a package in Node, you need to "require" it by:

`const fs = require("fs");`


where the variable is the name it is available as, require is the keyword and the name of the module is in the brackets following require.


To use a method in the package:


`fs.someMethod()`

###In order to start using NPM:

1. You have to initialise NPM inside your project by using the `npm init` command to generate a *package.json*
2. Then you can install a package with `npm install `

card_children.subcard_body: Note that when installing a package, it will also install the dependencies those packages require, eventually leading to Log4j.

### Getting Started
In order to start any web development project in Node with Express, you have to make a new directory, create a new root JS file (e.g. server.js or index.js), initialise NPM, and then install Express.

Here are the [install instructions](http://expressjs.com/en/starter/installing.html) for Express.

card_children.subcard_body: This is a method that handles what the server should do if it received a GET request. It takes two parameters -- the URL, and the callback function that tells the server what to do when GET is called.

Or it can be even shorter with an arrow function:


  `  app.get('/', (req, res) => { // Do a thing })`

We then use the `.send()` method to send a response back to the browser:


`app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.send("Hello!") })`

### `__dirname`
In order to send a template from Node to the browser, we use:


`res.sendFile(//name of file)`


But how will Node know where the file is? In order to get the specific file path we can use the `__dirname` keyword which will return the hard file path. So to serve up a template, you can simply:


`res.sendFile(__dirname + "/index.html")`
[Postman](http://www.postman.com) is a great tool for testing and working with APIs. It does a ton more than that, but for what I need those are the options I need the most.

Node has a native method for dealing with APIs called [HTTP and HTTPS](https://nodejs.dev/learn/making-http-requests-with-nodejs). Although their own documentation recommends Axios. One wonders why they don't just merge the two?

HTTP Requests arrive as raw data, to use it you need to convert it into JSON. To do so:


`JSON.parse(dataVariable)`


The opposite (to send data):


`JSON.stringify(dataToSend)`

When sending lines of HTML from Node to the browser, you can only ever have a single `res.send()` function call. But! You can have multiple lines of `res.write()`, so:


`res.write(//first line of HTML)`
`res.write(//another line of HTML)`
`res.write(//and another line of HTML)`


`res.send()`
